snippet.textDisplay: Its amazing to me how differently people can see things. You worry more about gameplay than an amazing story, but for me, why else would you play an RPG except for an amazing story? I would worry more about gameplay when it comes to Action/Adventure games.
snippet.textOriginal: Its amazing to me how differently people can see things. You worry more about gameplay than an amazing story, but for me, why else would you play an RPG except for an amazing story? I would worry more about gameplay when it comes to Action/Adventure games.

snippet.textDisplay: I personally wouldn't play a game for 50+ hours if I didn't like the gameplay no matter how good the story is, that's all.
snippet.textOriginal: I personally wouldn't play a game for 50+ hours if I didn't like the gameplay no matter how good the story is, that's all.

snippet.textDisplay: The Etrian Odyssey games are all about gameplay, and they''re a turn based rpg. I mean, there's a story mode for the remakes, but I don't really care for that personally.
snippet.textOriginal: The Etrian Odyssey games are all about gameplay, and they''re a turn based rpg. I mean, there's a story mode for the remakes, but I don't really care for that personally.

snippet.textDisplay: A game having an amazing story doesn't mean much if it doesn't play well, as you have to be able to want to be compelled to keep playing and a frustrating gameplay system can deter that.  Stories are a top in thing in RPGs no doubt, but to act like the gameplay isn't important is naive.
snippet.textOriginal: A game having an amazing story doesn't mean much if it doesn't play well, as you have to be able to want to be compelled to keep playing and a frustrating gameplay system can deter that.  Stories are a top in thing in RPGs no doubt, but to act like the gameplay isn't important is naive.

snippet.textDisplay: I tend to focus on both. Then again, I can't think of any RPG with an excellent story that doesn't also have great gameplay. Well, I suppose Xenogears and Xenosaga were a bit simplistic, but I enjoyed them anyways.
snippet.textOriginal: I tend to focus on both. Then again, I can't think of any RPG with an excellent story that doesn't also have great gameplay. Well, I suppose Xenogears and Xenosaga were a bit simplistic, but I enjoyed them anyways.

snippet.textDisplay: +DAWells1983 I so agree with you. Not many people think like us.
snippet.textOriginal: +DAWells1983 I so agree with you. Not many people think like us.

snippet.textDisplay: +DAWells1983 I agree with that, but I have to add one more criteria on top. For me, the way the story is told is what is most important. While gameplay comes into play it is not the most important, you are correct there. But without a good score the story will fall flat for me. I need the right emotions to emphasize certain parts of a story. This is basically what made me latch on to Wild Arms as much as I did when I was a kid. The story was awesome, the game looked awesome, gameplay was, well, it was an RPG. But the music was phenomenal! It drew me in and never let go. Still hasn't.
snippet.textOriginal: +DAWells1983 I agree with that, but I have to add one more criteria on top. For me, the way the story is told is what is most important. While gameplay comes into play it is not the most important, you are correct there. But without a good score the story will fall flat for me. I need the right emotions to emphasize certain parts of a story. This is basically what made me latch on to Wild Arms as much as I did when I was a kid. The story was awesome, the game looked awesome, gameplay was, well, it was an RPG. But the music was phenomenal! It drew me in and never let go. Still hasn't.

snippet.textDisplay: @DAWells1983 Hm I think I get your way of thinking. I understand it, although I think I could never finish a game whose gameplay doesn't appeal to me. I got you when you said that it's like reading a book. As for the Wild Arms thing, I'm a huge fan of the series precisely because its gameplay is, at least for me, way more fun than your average RPG; you know, with all those little puzzles, character tools and everything XD and of course the music as well.
snippet.textOriginal: @DAWells1983 Hm I think I get your way of thinking. I understand it, although I think I could never finish a game whose gameplay doesn't appeal to me. I got you when you said that it's like reading a book. As for the Wild Arms thing, I'm a huge fan of the series precisely because its gameplay is, at least for me, way more fun than your average RPG; you know, with all those little puzzles, character tools and everything XD and of course the music as well.

snippet.textDisplay: Well, we'lI have to agree to disagree. To me, the story should always be the main focus. At least when it comes to RPG's. Im not looking for an amazing story in a fighting game. Game play should definitely be the focus there. For me, playing a really good RPG is no different that reading a good book. The only difference is that you play a part in the story because you guide your characters through the plot. Do you see what I mean? I mean, look at a game like Dragon Warrior 7. Game play is terrible, but quite possibly one of the best stories in any RPG that I've ever played. I take it by your Van Burace name that you are a fan of the first Wild Arms? Well, the game play in that wasn't anything special. Not by a long shot. But that story was epic.
snippet.textOriginal: Well, we'lI have to agree to disagree. To me, the story should always be the main focus. At least when it comes to RPG's. Im not looking for an amazing story in a fighting game. Game play should definitely be the focus there. For me, playing a really good RPG is no different that reading a good book. The only difference is that you play a part in the story because you guide your characters through the plot. Do you see what I mean? I mean, look at a game like Dragon Warrior 7. Game play is terrible, but quite possibly one of the best stories in any RPG that I've ever played. I take it by your Van Burace name that you are a fan of the first Wild Arms? Well, the game play in that wasn't anything special. Not by a long shot. But that story was epic.

snippet.textDisplay: @DAWells1983 To me, any game's main focus should be gameplay. that's why it's a game. I appreciate it when the story is good, don't get me wrong, but if I am only looking for an amazing story then I have thousands of movies, TV shows and books that focus almost solely on the story.
snippet.textOriginal: @DAWells1983 To me, any game's main focus should be gameplay. that's why it's a game. I appreciate it when the story is good, don't get me wrong, but if I am only looking for an amazing story then I have thousands of movies, TV shows and books that focus almost solely on the story.

How is this this for lyrics, do you think?

I closed my eyes, heard the wind pass through the swaying trees, felt it lift me up into the sky with the birds, 
it's peaceful, so peaceful out here.

Took my time, found the place that sang unto my soul, escaped the barren earth i left behind long ago, im free now,
so free now im here.

(the starting line is intentional :P)

snippet.textDisplay: I haven't tried part 1 yet, but I have a copy of Alter Code F tucked away for a rainy day (or month). I don't really mind if the game is repetitive, as long as the puzzles get harder and the gameplay is pretty solid. I actually don't like it when an RPG tries to be some major set-piece production like Final Fantasy X. If I want an amazing story, I'll just read a book. WA3's dungeons and world reminded me of the great Zelda games for SNES/GBA. No killer story but great unbroken gameplay.
snippet.textOriginal: I haven't tried part 1 yet, but I have a copy of Alter Code F tucked away for a rainy day (or month). I don't really mind if the game is repetitive, as long as the puzzles get harder and the gameplay is pretty solid. I actually don't like it when an RPG tries to be some major set-piece production like Final Fantasy X. If I want an amazing story, I'll just read a book. WA3's dungeons and world reminded me of the great Zelda games for SNES/GBA. No killer story but great unbroken gameplay.

snippet.textDisplay: I think I mentioned it is one of the few games where I bothered with the sidequests. But compared to how refreshing part one was back in 96. You were learning moves in towns and dungeons with Jack. The girl's and guy's were interesting. There was a dungeon in the desert. Interesting plot points like the sky falling and a town with a demon barrier at its entrance. It felt repetitive, and the dungeons weren't visually distinctive. I did end up liking the game though.
snippet.textOriginal: I think I mentioned it is one of the few games where I bothered with the sidequests. But compared to how refreshing part one was back in 96. You were learning moves in towns and dungeons with Jack. The girl's and guy's were interesting. There was a dungeon in the desert. Interesting plot points like the sky falling and a town with a demon barrier at its entrance. It felt repetitive, and the dungeons weren't visually distinctive. I did end up liking the game though.

snippet.textDisplay: That's interesting. I think Symphonia is probably a harder game. But the puzzles were so weak they might as well not have existed. The only interesting one was when you had to write down some sentences that were in semi code.
snippet.textOriginal: That's interesting. I think Symphonia is probably a harder game. But the puzzles were so weak they might as well not have existed. The only interesting one was when you had to write down some sentences that were in semi code.

snippet.textDisplay: WA3 was the first game in the series that I played and I found its style to be incredibly refreshing and solid. It takes a bit to grow on you, but the payoff is excellent. I also appreciated the sheer size of the quest, which in terms of most newer RPGs, is pretty remarkable.
snippet.textOriginal: WA3 was the first game in the series that I played and I found its style to be incredibly refreshing and solid. It takes a bit to grow on you, but the payoff is excellent. I also appreciated the sheer size of the quest, which in terms of most newer RPGs, is pretty remarkable.

snippet.textDisplay: I just started Wild ARMS 4, and while it plays great and the style is solid, I'm wondering why they had to get rid of the world map. Some people claimed it was tedious, but I loved searching the globe in Wild ARMS 3 and finding the dungeons, Millenium Puzzles, etc... not to mention how intimidatingly HUGE the world was. I guess the developers felt like they had to adhere more to Final Fantasy X's example, which is unfortunate.
snippet.textOriginal: I just started Wild ARMS 4, and while it plays great and the style is solid, I'm wondering why they had to get rid of the world map. Some people claimed it was tedious, but I loved searching the globe in Wild ARMS 3 and finding the dungeons, Millenium Puzzles, etc... not to mention how intimidatingly HUGE the world was. I guess the developers felt like they had to adhere more to Final Fantasy X's example, which is unfortunate.

snippet.textDisplay:
It doesn't matter. The stories are mostly unrelated, though the setting is the same world.

After putting out #3, they reissued #1 on the PS2 as 'Alter-Code F' and gave it virtually the same engine/gameplay-mechanics as #3.

It's interesting that you mention Tales of Symphonia and Wild ARMS 3 in the same post, as though are the last two games I played through. I really enjoyed Symphonia, but WA3 was a much more satisfying challenge. Symphonia's dungeon-crawling sections were way too easy.
snippet.textOriginal:
It doesn't matter. The stories are mostly unrelated, though the setting is the same world.

After putting out #3, they reissued #1 on the PS2 as 'Alter-Code F' and gave it virtually the same engine/gameplay-mechanics as #3.

It's interesting that you mention Tales of Symphonia and Wild ARMS 3 in the same post, as though are the last two games I played through. I really enjoyed Symphonia, but WA3 was a much more satisfying challenge. Symphonia's dungeon-crawling sections were way too easy.

snippet.textDisplay: I consider it the weakest in the series of the ones I've played(not 4 or the psp ones). It still has its own unique charm that grows on you. Also it has the honor of being the last wild arms where the women are fully clothed.
snippet.textOriginal: I consider it the weakest in the series of the ones I've played(not 4 or the psp ones). It still has its own unique charm that grows on you. Also it has the honor of being the last wild arms where the women are fully clothed.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a big fan of the first Wild Arms game.  I really need to work my way through the rest of the series and give the remake a shot.
